proposals.reasoning: Most people were leaning toward including Alice as a low‑info, baseline pick, and I still like that logic. As leader, I also prefer to put myself on the first mission so I can directly contribute to the information we get from it rather than just steering from the outside. This lineup keeps one widely accepted player (Alice) while giving the table a clear record of my own early involvement and mission result for future scrutiny.

votes.comment: Leader deviated from the Alice+Charlie consensus to include themselves; that shift feels like an unnecessary risk on Mission 1 when we had a simpler baseline option.
I’d rather stick with the earlier consensus of Alice + Charlie for a cleaner baseline; putting you on as leader feels like a shift from what we’d just been aligning on.
The table consensus was Alice + me for a clean baseline; swapping me for Eve without new info adds unnecessary risk and gives us less clarity if it fails.
My teammate is on the mission with a widely trusted pick, giving evil a strong shot to sabotage while keeping suspicion low.
I’m on the team and it keeps suspicion low while still giving us early info.

proposals.reasoning: Consensus across the table favors Alice + Charlie as a low-information, low-risk starting team. As Alice, I know I am good, so including myself guarantees at least one good player on the mission. Choosing Charlie lets us gather early data on his alignment while matching the lineup that Bob, Charlie, Diana, and Eve all tentatively support. The voting patterns on this commonly proposed team will be informative, and if the mission fails, suspicion will naturally focus on Charlie and (secondarily) on Bob for strongly steering this lineup.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, and an Alice+Charlie team is a standard low-info first mission that gives us useful data without overcomplicating early reads.
Neither known evil is on the team, so this is a relatively safe first mission and gives useful info from the result and voting patterns.
First mission with minimal info; I trust myself and want an early data point on Alice and on who supports/opposes this widely discussed lineup.
First mission with two likely goods is low-risk and rejecting a strong-consensus team would draw unnecessary suspicion.
Consistent with my earlier support for Alice + Charlie as a reasonable low-info first mission to gather baseline data.

discussion.content: Since it’s the first mission and we have almost no info, I’d lean toward a team of people who’ve been calm and consistent so far—maybe something like me plus one other, and we watch the voting patterns closely.

For the first mission I’d rather keep it simple and low‑risk: I’m comfortable with a team like Alice and Charlie so we can get an early read without overcomplicating things. We should avoid putting anyone who’s been pushing too hard for specific lineups onto this very first quest.

I’m okay with a simple Alice + me team to start, but I don’t want us to just auto‑trust early volunteers—if this first mission fails, we should be ready to scrutinize both Bob’s suggestion and whoever pushed hardest for that lineup.
I’m fine starting with Alice + Charlie since it gives us a clean baseline, but if it fails we should look just as hard at Bob for steering that lineup as at the people on it.

I’m okay with Alice + Charlie for the first mission since it lines up with what most people are leaning toward, but even if it passes we shouldn’t auto‑clear either of them or Bob for suggesting it—early missions can give a false sense of security.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Alice and Charlie was clean, so keeping that core minimizes the number of unknowns we introduce at once. For the third slot, between me and Eve, I think it’s better to test the person who’s already openly volunteered and has been willing to be under scrutiny, rather than someone who has argued to avoid me being too safe but hasn’t actually taken that test yet. If this team succeeds again, we’ll have a strong, consistent block to reason from; if it fails, the blame is tightly focused and gives us clearer information than if we start swapping out the previously successful pair.

votes.comment: Keeping the successful Alice–Charlie core and testing Bob as the only new variable gives clear info if it fails, and there’s no strong reason yet to prefer Eve over Bob.
Keeping the successful Alice-Charlie core and adding just one new person gives us focused information while minimizing risk this early.
I know I’m good, mission 1’s Alice–Charlie success gives Alice a slight trust edge, and testing Bob now gives clear info if it fails; this team is likely 2+ good and informative.
I still prefer testing Eve over Bob here so Bob doesn’t skate by untested; this team ignores that concern and keeps him too insulated.
I still prefer keeping Alice and Charlie but adding me instead of Bob so we don’t let Bob go untested for too long and spread the early scrutiny more evenly.

discussion.content: Given that the first mission with me and Charlie went clean, I’d strongly prefer keeping that core and adding just one new person rather than swapping in multiple unknowns at once.

Sticking with Alice and Charlie makes sense to me, and we just need one more person who’s comfortable being under a bit of scrutiny if anything goes wrong. I’m happy to volunteer for that third spot, but if people prefer someone else, I’d still lean toward only changing one slot from the proven pair.

I like keeping me and Alice together for now, but we should remember that an all-success first mission doesn’t clear either of us completely, so I’d rather we talk through who feels most transparent as the third (including Bob) before we lock it in.

Keeping Alice and Charlie together seems fine, but I’d rather not just reward the first volunteer—between Bob and Eve, I slightly prefer adding Eve this round so Bob isn’t too insulated from scrutiny later.

I’m fine keeping Alice and Charlie as the core, and between Bob and me I slightly prefer myself this round just so we don’t end up with Bob cruising by on never being tested early. If people are nervous about that, though, I’d want to hear a concrete reason for preferring Bob over me rather than just defaulting to him.

proposals.reasoning: Both previous missions that included Alice and Charlie succeeded with 0 FAIL cards, including one where Bob was added. The only pair that has been tested twice and remained clean is Alice + Charlie, which maximizes the probability of a third success. At 2–0, good only needs one more success, so prioritizing the safest, most proven combo is better than introducing new information risk with a different team.

votes.comment: This is the only pair that’s been clean twice; at 2–0 we should prioritize the safest-known combo to secure the win rather than introduce new variables.
This is the most proven combo so far—both have been on only clean missions, so at 2–0 I’d rather stick with what’s already worked than add new risk.

I know I’m good, and repeating the only fully tested pair (Alice + Charlie) is our best shot at an all-good team. The resistance from Diana and Eve makes me more inclined to think this pair is dangerous for evil, so I’m happy to run it for a potential game-winning mission.
I’m still wary of repeating the same Alice + Charlie combo a third time; if there is a hidden evil there, we’ll never see it by autopiloting this team.
At 2–0 this team auto-wins for good with no evil on it; we need a team including someone new to actually contest the mission.

discussion.content: Given both missions with me and Charlie (and the second with Bob) have passed cleanly, I’m most comfortable keeping this team to two from that group—I'd strongly lean Alice + Charlie again unless someone has a compelling reason to swap.
Sticking with the Alice + Charlie core seems safest right now—two clean missions with that combo is hard to argue with. I’d rather not introduce new variables when we’re already at 2–0.

I like keeping the team within the proven group, but if we’re only sending two I slightly prefer Alice + Charlie again since that’s the only combo that’s been clean twice. If anyone has a strong read that Bob is 100% good, I’m open to Alice + Bob too, but let’s not bring in new people now.

I get why everyone wants to default to Alice + Charlie, but two clean missions don’t actually confirm both are good—if there’s a coordinated evil in there, repeating that pair could be exactly what they want. I’d feel a bit safer mixing it up with Alice + Bob this time so we’re not tunnel-visioned on one combo.

I’m a bit uneasy just autopiloting Alice + Charlie again—if that pair is hiding an evil, we’ll never see it. I’d rather try Alice + Bob this round so we at least get some new info instead of locking in the same combo.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning toward Bob as Merlin—he’s consistently nudging us toward the safest, lowest‑variance lineups (Alice + Charlie core, minimal changes) without ever looking like he’s driving things too hard. Alice feels a bit *too* out front and opinionated for Merlin and would know all three of them are good anyway, while Charlie mostly reacts and caveats rather than subtly steering; Bob’s “I’m fine either way, but this is the solid, conservative option” tone screams informed but trying not to look it.

I’m with Diana that Bob pings Merlin the hardest for me: he keeps subtly reinforcing the “safe” Alice+Charlie core, always sounding flexible while consistently pushing the lowest‑info, lowest‑variance options. Alice feels too loud and agenda‑setting (more like a confident regular good), and Charlie’s hedging reads more like genuine uncertainty than informed steering, whereas Bob’s calm “I’m fine either way, but…” posture looks like someone protecting known goods without ever sticking his neck out.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Bob repeatedly and calmly guided the table toward the lowest-variance, safest teams built around Alice + Charlie, consistently reinforcing already-clean cores while avoiding strong, risky pushes. His flexible, "I’m fine either way, but this is the solid option" posture fits an informed Merlin subtly protecting known goods more than Alice’s front-foot leadership or Charlie’s more reactive hedging.
